Blight.description: Blight causes rapid browning and death of leaves, stems, or fruits due to fungal or bacterial infection.

Leaf Spot.description: Leaf spot appears as small, circular, discolored spots that can merge and cause leaf death.
preventive_measures: Use fungicides such as mancozeb or chlorothalonil.
Practice crop rotation with non-host plants.

Rust.description: Rust forms orange, brown, or yellow pustules on leaves and stems, reducing plant vigor.

Smut.description: Smut replaces grains or kernels with black, powdery fungal spores.

Mildew.description: Mildew causes white or gray fuzzy growth on leaves, reducing photosynthesis.
preventive_measures: Spray neem oil or sulfur-based fungicides.

Canker.description: Canker forms sunken, dead areas on stems, branches, or fruits, restricting nutrient flow.

Wilt.description: Wilt causes drooping and yellowing due to infection blocking the plant’s vascular system.

Rot.description: Rot leads to soft, decayed plant tissues caused by fungi or bacteria, often starting underground.

Anthracnose.description: Anthracnose causes dark, sunken lesions on leaves, stems, or fruits.

Damping-Off.description: Damping-off causes seedlings to collapse due to soil-borne fungi attacking roots.
preventive_measures: Treat seeds with fungicides before planting.

Scab.description: Scab produces corky, raised lesions on fruits, leaves, or tubers.

Mold.description: Mold appears as fuzzy fungal growth on leaves, stems, or fruits in humid conditions.

Gall.description: Galls are abnormal swellings on plant tissues caused by bacteria, fungi, or insects.

Mosaic Disease.description: Mosaic disease causes mottled yellow and green patches on leaves, stunting growth.

Leaf Curl.description: Leaf curl causes leaves to twist, thicken, and discolor due to viral or pest attack.
preventive_measures: Avoid continuous cropping of susceptible hosts.

Streak Disease.description: Streak disease causes linear streaks on leaves, reducing photosynthetic area.

Dieback.description: Dieback causes progressive death of twigs and branches from the tips.

Bunchy Top.description: Bunchy top causes shortened internodes and leaves clustered at the top.

Yellowing.description: Yellowing results from nutrient deficiency or infection causing chlorosis in leaves.

Tip Burn.description: Tip burn causes browning and necrosis at leaf edges due to calcium deficiency or stress.

Tumor.description: Tumors are abnormal swellings caused by bacterial infection, often at wounds.

Phyllody.description: Phyllody converts floral parts into leafy structures due to phytoplasma infection.

Witches’ Broom.description: Witches’ broom causes excessive shoot branching and leaf clustering due to phytoplasmas or fungi.

Little Leaf.description: Little leaf causes small, narrow leaves and stunted growth due to phytoplasma infection.

Leaf Blotch.description: Leaf blotch creates irregular brown or dark patches on leaves, reducing photosynthesis.

Shot Hole Disease.description: Shot hole disease causes round holes in leaves due to fungal or bacterial infection.

Sooty Mold.description: Sooty mold forms a black coating on leaves due to fungal growth on insect secretions.
preventive_measures: Wash off mold using mild soap solution.

Spot Blotch.description: Spot blotch causes dark brown spots that merge into blotches, reducing yield.

Black Rot.description: Black rot causes dark lesions on leaves and fruit, leading to rot and defoliation.

Soft Rot.description: Soft rot leads to watery, foul-smelling tissue breakdown in vegetables and roots.
preventive_measures: Store produce in cool, dry conditions.

Brown Rot.description: Brown rot affects fruits, causing brown spots and moldy growth.

Collar Rot.description: Collar rot attacks the base of stems near the soil line, causing wilting and death.

Stem Canker.description: Stem canker forms sunken lesions on stems, restricting nutrient flow.

Root Knot.description: Root knot nematodes cause galls or swellings on roots, reducing nutrient uptake.

Leaf Scorch.description: Leaf scorch causes leaf edges to dry and brown due to bacterial infection or drought.

Vascular Wilt.description: Vascular wilt blocks water movement through xylem, leading to wilting and death.

Fruit Spot.description: Fruit spot causes small, dark, sunken lesions on fruits that expand during storage.
preventive_measures: Store fruits in dry, cool areas.

Silver Leaf.description: Silver leaf causes a silvery sheen on leaves and internal wood discoloration.

Fire Blight.description: Fire blight causes wilting and blackening of flowers and branches, resembling fire damage.
preventive_measures: Prune infected parts well below lesions.
Apply streptomycin or copper sprays preventively.

Bacterial Blight.description: Bacterial blight causes water-soaked lesions that turn brown or black on leaves.

Leaf Blight.description: Leaf blight leads to large brown patches on leaves, causing premature drying.

Early Blight.description: Early blight produces concentric dark spots on lower leaves and stems.

Late Blight.description: Late blight causes water-soaked lesions on leaves and fruits, spreading rapidly in humidity.

Leaf Rust.description: Leaf rust forms orange pustules mainly on leaf surfaces, reducing photosynthesis.

Stripe Rust.description: Stripe rust forms yellow or orange stripes on leaves, leading to premature drying.

Powdery Scab.description: Powdery scab forms raised warty lesions on tubers and roots caused by soil-borne protozoa.

Downy Mold.description: Downy mold causes yellow patches on leaves with gray mold underneath.

Web Blight.description: Web blight causes web-like mycelial growth on leaves and stems under humid conditions.

Black Spot.description: Black spot produces round black lesions on leaves, reducing photosynthetic efficiency.

Cercospora Leaf Spot.description: Cercospora leaf spot causes small gray lesions with purple margins, leading to defoliation.
